sentences.sentence: I had now conceived( 设想 ) the utmost( 极度的 ) horror of the man, not only for this cold-blooded business in which he had been concerned, but even more for the casual and heartless way in which he told it.
Whatever punishment was in store for( 即将发生在 ) him, he might expect no sympathy from me.
Sherlock Holmes and Jones sat with their hands upon their knees, deeply interested in the story, but with the same disgust written upon their faces.
He may have noticed it, for there was a touch of defiance( 蔑视 ) in his voice and manner as he continued.
“It was my life or his once he was in the fort( 城堡 ).
If he had got out, the whole business would come to light, and I should have been found guilty and shot as likely as not, for people were not very merciful at a time like that.”
“Go on with your story,” said Holmes, shortly.
“Well, we carried him in, Abdullah, Akbar, and I. Though short, he was heavy.
Mahomet Singh was left to guard the door.
We took him to a place which the Sikhs had already prepared. It was some distance off, where a winding passage leads to a great empty hall.
The earth floor had sunk in at one place, making a natural grave( 坟墓 ), so we left Achmet the merchant there, having first covered him over with loose bricks.
This done, we all went back to the treasure.
It lay where he had dropped it. The box was the same which now lies open upon your table.
A key was attached by a cord to that carved handle upon the top.
We opened it, and the light of the lantern shone upon a collection of jewels just as I had dreamed about all my life.
It was blinding to look upon them.
We took them all out and made a list of them.
There were one hundred and forty-three perfect diamonds, over six hundred other precious stones, and nearly three hundred very fine pearls( 珍珠 ), twelve of which were set in a gold crown( 王冠 ).
By the way, these last had been taken out of the chest and were not there when I recovered it.
After we had counted our treasures, we put them back into the chest and carried them to the gateway( 入口 ) to show to Mahomet Singh.
Then we agreed to hide our loot( 战利品 ) in a safe place until the country should be at peace again, and then to divide it equally among ourselves.
There was no use dividing it at present, for if jewels of such value were found upon us it would cause suspicion( 怀疑 ), and there was no privacy in the fort( 城堡 ).
We carried the box, therefore, into the same hall where we had buried the body, and there, under certain bricks in the best-preserved wall, we made a hollow( 浅坑 ) and put our treasure.
We made careful note of the place, and next day I drew four plans, one for each of us, and put the sign of the four of us at the bottom, for we had sworn that we should each always act for all.
That is an oath( 誓言 ) that I swear I have never broken.
Well, you know the history of the Indian rebellion( 叛乱 ).
The rebels( 叛军 ) were defeated, and we four were hoping to escape with our shares of the loot( 战利品 ).
But our hopes were shattered( 粉碎 ) by our being arrested as the murderers of Achmet.
It happened like this. The rajah( 王侯 ) had sent another servant to spy upon the first.
This second man followed Achmet like his shadow. He went after him that night and saw him pass through the doorway.
When he entered the fort( 城堡 ) the next day, he could find no trace( 踪迹 ) of Achmet.
He spoke about it to a surgeon( 军医 ), who told the commander.
A thorough search was quickly made, and the body was discovered.
Thus at the very moment that we thought that all was safe we were all four seized and brought to trial on a charge of( 以...的罪名 ) murder. All four of us were imprisoned for life.
Not a word about the jewels came out at the trial, for the rajah( 王侯 ) had been deposed and driven out of India: so no one had any particular interest in them.
There we were all four with almost no chance of ever being free again, while we each held a secret which might have put each of us in a palace if we could only have made use of it.
It was enough to make a man eat his heart out( （因希望不会实现而）极度不快 ) to have to put up with( 忍受 ) all kinds of abuse, to have rice to eat and water to drink, with a fortune waiting for him outside.
It might have driven me mad; but I was always a pretty stubborn one, so I just held on and waited for my time.
At last it seemed to me to have come. I was moved from Agra to Madras, and from there to Blair Island in the Andamans.
There are very few white prisoners at this settlement, and, as I had behaved well from the first, I soon found myself a sort of privileged person.
I was given a hut( 小屋 ) in Hope Town, which is a small place on the slopes( 山坡 ) of Mount Harriet, and I was left pretty much to myself.
It is a dreary( 沉闷的 ), unhealthy place, and all beyond our little clearings were wild cannibal( 食人族 ) natives, who were ready enough to blow a poisoned dart( 刺 ) at us if they saw a chance.
There was digging and farm-work, so we were busy enough all day, though in the evening we had a little time to ourselves.
I learned to give out drugs for the surgeon( 军医 ), and picked up( 获得 ) a little of his knowledge.
All the time I was looking for a chance of escape; but it is hundreds of miles from any other land, and there is little or no wind in those seas: so it was a terribly difficult job to get away.
The surgeon( 军医 ) liked to gamble( 赌博 ) and the other young officers would meet in his rooms in the evening and play cards.
The surgery( 诊所 ), where I used to make up my drugs, was next to his sitting-room, with a small window between us.
Often, if I felt lonely, I used to turn out the lamp in the surgery( 诊所 ), and then, standing there, I could hear their talk and watch their play.
There was Major Sholto, Captain Morstan, and Lieutenant Bromley Brown, who were in command of( 管辖 ) the native troops, and there was the surgeon( 军医 ) himself, and two or three prison-officials.
